newsitem.title: UK: EMERGING MARKET OUTLOOK-Eyes on Russia, Bulgaria.
newsitem.headline: EMERGING MARKET OUTLOOK-Eyes on Russia, Bulgaria.

text.p: A strong run so far for emerging markets in 1997 could slow this week as investors pause for breath, but analysts say a longer term uptrend remains intact.

They said holidays in some markets were likely to keep a lid on moves until later in the week, with a positive tone expected for emerging European markets and a consolidation possible in Latin America.
In RUSSIA, the Federation Council upper house of parliament is due to debate the 1997 budget, but this should be a formality.
The IMF decided on Friday to release $650 million of its $10 billion three-year loan to Russia, providing a vote of confidence for the country's painful economic reform programme.
The IMF delayed paying two tranches of the three-year loan in the last quarter of 1996 but decided to release the January tranche and one of the delayed payments.

The market will continue to watch for clues about the health of Russian President Boris Yeltsin, and preparations for a planned mark Eurobond offering of about $1 billion in early March could attract some attention.
BULGARIA waits for its new caretaker cabinet, expected to be led by Sofia's respected mayor Stefan Sofianski.
It will take office once parliament has cleared outstanding business and a session is scheduled for Tuesday or Wednesday.
The Socialists agreed to hold elections on April 20 and analysts said the decision had boosted sentiment but cautioned that further hiccups could be expected.

"There is a question how much co-operation a new government will get from the Socialists...The formation of the cabinet could provide a dose of realism by not co-operating with the UDF (opposition coalition)," said Jonathan Hoffman, director of economics at CSFB.
Hoffman said ROMANIA would attract attention in coming weeks with the new government expected to come up with some tough measures on economic reform.

Prime Minister Victor Ciobrea said recently a tough reform programme being drafted by his centrist government was Romania's last chance to avoid sliding into an economic crisis like neighbouring Bulgaria.
POLAND's newly appointed Finance Minister Marek Belka will be closely watched to see how firm he stands in the face of any political pressure, analysts said.
Belka has pledged policy continuity following his appointment on Tuesday when Grzegorz Kolodko quit after three years in the post.
In BRAZIL, a carnival holiday on Monday and Tuesday will cap activity, but after a strong month and generally positive news in recent weeks a mild correction could be in store.
"There has been a lot of good news from Brazil and we could see a bit of a correction...but we still like it," Alan Livsey, head of Latam research at Kleinwort Benson said.
He said ARGENTINA, like many Latin American markets, may need a short term rest after a recent strong run, with a protracted struggle over labour reforms under the spotlight.

Government, unions and business were due to meet on Friday over the reforms. The government and the CGT labour federation cut off all talks after a strike on December 26 to protest at attempts to reform labour law and reduce union power by presidential decree.
CHILE's move to cut interbank daily interest rates by 0.25 percentage points could draw some interest, if foreign investors latch onto it as a signal of monetary policy easing this year.
A big day for U.S. figures on Friday could also influence direction in emerging markets, analysts said, with PPI, industrial production and capacity utilisation figures due.
ECUADOR is set for a bumpy ride after the ousting by Congress of President Abdala Bucaram on Thursday. Vice-President Rosalia Arteaga was appointed interim president on Monday.

A positive speech at the opening of parliament by SOUTH AFRICAN president Nelson Mandela on Friday could aid a further rally in the rand, which has made strong ground so far in 1997 amid renewed portfolio interest.
Analysts said the speech contained little fresh news but should encourage buoyant investor sentiment.

The IFC emerging market composite investable index, IFC/IPRD, denominated in dollars, closed up 2.2 percent from a week previously at 322.29 points on Friday. In the year to date it has gained 9.2 percent.
Latin America was at 604.24, 3.0 percent up from a week previously, Asia was up 0.7 percent at 262.91 and Europe, Middle East and Africa was quoted at 156.07, up 4.1 percent.
--London Newsroom +44 171 542 2734
